stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the game's overworld, focusing on level design philosophy (using natural barriers), connecting different areas, and tackling the significant technical challenge of implementing a dynamic, localized fog effect for the Ghost Ship entrance. He also elaborated on the project's custom engine and his personal design principles.

development_findings.summary: The project has evolved far beyond a standard ROM hack, with Kaze having replaced the vast majority of the original SM64 engine, including rendering, camera, animations (moving to quaternions), and even the underlying operating system.
development_findings.quote: What you probably don't realize is that like almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point. The only really thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has systematically replaced core rendering components of the original game to achieve his specific visual and technical goals, demonstrating a deep re-engineering of the base game.
development_findings.quote: The way the coins are rendered is completely different... the way mario is rendered is also completely different... I entirely ripped out the mario 64 skybox system because it's hideous.

development_findings.summary: The overworld features non-linear progression, where players must complete objectives in later parts of the game (like unlocking an 'ice cap') to access earlier areas, such as the Ghost Ship level.
development_findings.quote: You need to reach the lighthouse first... But to get to the lighthouse you need to unlock the ice cap.

development_findings.summary: Kaze employs an iterative and non-sequential development process for the overworld, blocking out multiple areas concurrently rather than perfecting one at a time to avoid rework as the interconnected world takes shape.
development_findings.quote: When we work on the other areas we will likely have to adjust this one again. So if we do that we waste a shit ton of time. That's why we don't do that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze actively avoids using simple cliffs as barriers, instead brainstorming more diegetic and creative solutions like giant fruit, forests, and ruins to make the world feel more natural and cohesive.
development_findings.quote: The problem is it's so lame if everything's just cliffed up, right? I don't like if everything's just cliffed up. Is there other natural barriers we could use?

development_findings.summary: A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to solving the technical challenge of creating a dynamic, localized fog effect on N64 hardware, combining hardware fog controlled by code with transparent 3D planes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze clarifies that while he does take on paid commissions for other ROM hacks, 'Return to Yoshi's Island' is a purely passion-driven project with no financial incentive.
context_findings.quote: There's a lot of money to be made in romhacking. But this one here is not any paid work at all. This is just me working because of passion.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that variety and contrast, even through less-liked sections, are essential for a game's overall design to be successful.
context_findings.quote: Sometimes the part that people least like about the game are also the parts that are most necessary to make the game's design work.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds the philosophy that for most use cases, the choice of programming language is less important than the programmer's skill, and enjoys challenging conventional wisdom on topics like performance.
context_findings.quote: I think only really bad programmers care about which programming language they use for most applications.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on how his cognitive abilities have shifted over time, feeling he has become highly specialized in game design problem-solving at the expense of other skills, like theoretical math.
context_findings.quote: Sometimes I feel like I'm getting older and my brain doesn't work like it used to anymore. And then I also think that maybe my neurons just got more optimized... I'm bad at the things I want to be good at and the ones I practiced and worse at things that I didn't practice.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses significant frustration with the instability of development tools like NVIDIA Broadcast and OBS, which crashed during the stream.
context_findings.quote: Why are there so many dogshit programmers working on all this software?

context_findings.summary: Kaze is actively considering the legal requirements to make the game a sellable product, identifying the remaining Nintendo assets (sound engine, Mario's core actions) that would need to be replaced.
The stream was a 'bonus stream' on Kaze's day off, and he ended it feeling 'a little burned out,' indicating the personal time and energy investment required for the project.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for the final visual and geometry 'rework' of the overworld levels after Kaze completes the initial layout and functionality.
biobak.quote: I'd like to see the Biobak rework of the overworld.

biobak.summary: Biobak has already completed a visual rework of at least one level, 'ZooZooZoo', improving its appearance.
biobak.quote: ZooZooZoo did get a rework already so that's why it's looking better.

zeina.summary: Zeina (as 'Dainy Fox') provided a suggestion for the fog effect. Kaze initially dismissed it bluntly but later acknowledged its merit, revealing a direct and unfiltered creative dynamic between them.
zeina.quote: Maybe sometimes you have good ideas, and you just don't communicate them correctly. Which would be tragic. You should work on that.

zeina.summary: Zeina created a concept render of the ghost ship, suggesting her contributions extend to concept art and visual direction beyond her primary role as an animator.
zeina.quote: Did you just make the ship for this render? Interesting.

key_stories.title: Implementing the Ghost Ship Fog
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to create a dynamic fog effect that would act as a barrier to the Ghost Ship level. Through a live process of coding, debugging, and iteration, he overcame the N64's technical limitations to build a hybrid system that successfully creates a localized fog that responds to the player's position and view.
key_stories.challenge: Creating a convincing, localized, and dynamic fog effect around the Ghost Ship on N64 hardware, which doesn't natively support such effects easily. The fog needed to act as a gameplay barrier, intensifying as the player gets closer and looks at the ship.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed solutions, dismissing performantly-expensive ideas like multiple planes. He then began coding a solution live, struggling with the math and debugging inverted values. After feedback from Zeina and iterative testing, he realized the fog's intensity was non-linear and squared a value to create a smoother visual transition.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a hybrid solution using C code to manipulate the N64's hardware fog based on player distance and camera angle, combined with transparent 'fake fog' planes. The final effect creates a smooth transition where the ship is obscured, and getting too close warps the player away, fulfilling the design goal.
key_stories.key_quote: Our entire issue, 100% of our issue is that we want the fog to be around the ship. That's entirely the problem.

key_stories.title: Building a Custom Engine on N64
key_stories.summary: When asked why he doesn't use a modern engine, Kaze explained the immense scale of his technical work. He detailed how he has replaced nearly every part of the original Mario 64 engine, from rendering to the operating system, effectively creating his own custom engine on N64 hardware.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer questioned why Kaze doesn't use a modern engine, implying the project is a simple modification. This prompted Kaze to define the true technical scope and nature of the project.
key_stories.process: Kaze systematically listed the core components of the SM64 engine he has personally replaced: the renderer for objects and the skybox, the camera system, the animation data structure (moving to quaternions), and even the underlying operating system, which he is rewriting to be more optimized.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze established that the project is a fundamental re-engineering of the original game, not a simple hack. He has built a custom engine on top of the decompilation project, which justifies the N64-centric workflow and explains why porting to PC is not a simple or desirable alternative.
key_stories.key_quote: What you probably don't realize is that like almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point. The only really thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.
